.NET Rocks #362: James Kovacs Inverts Our Control!

Posted by James Kovacs on 2008/07/29

I had the pleasure of appearing on .NET Rocks #362. I talked to Carl and Richard about dependency inversion, dependency injection, and inversion of control. A lot of what we talked about I also wrote about in my MSDN article, Loosen Up: Tame Your Software Dependencies for More Flexible Apps. Here’s the summary of the show, which I had absolutely no input into whatsoever:

James Kovacs talks about the Castle Windsor project, and gives the clearest definitions of Inversion of Control (IOC) containers, Dependency Injection, and the reasons why we need to think about these techniques. Critical listening for all .NET developers.

I believe that I owe them both a beer next time I see them for such flattering remarks.

    I listened to this podcast yesterday and it was awesome. I just happen to be trying to _really_ “get” IoC and DI. I can honestly say I do, now. But the practical level which you spoke about DI also made me realize just how applicable (and important) DI is. Also want to thank you for your R# Jedi series, it helped me get to the next level with R#. And… while I’m here, I might as well admit something. I was at TechEd 2007 and I attended your “little discussion” mentioned in your “Why I Do What I Do” post. TechEd 2007 was an awakening for me. However, had I took what you said at that little discussion more to heart – I’d be at least 6 months ahead of where I am now. I know I’m on the right path now, but I also now know that the path was shown to me by you and I just didn’t see it back then. Regardless, triple thanks.

  • http://weblogs.asp.net/jdanforth Johan

    James, that was a great show, really. The praise from Carl and Richard is well deserved. The MSDN article is good reading too.

  • Brian Johnston

    I have to poke at you on one thing:

    >>>How confident are you that your data layer will only talk to SQL Server® or that you’ll always load your app settings from an XML document named Settings.xml? The intent here is not to build an infinitely extensible but hugely complex and unusable generic framework. It is about reversibility. How easily can you change your mind with respect to design decisions? Do you have an application architecture that responds well to change?<<<

    I think there’s an aspect your leaving out here, a very important one, and best explained by example:

    The application I inherited was decoupled, coincidently enough, from the settings files, the logging framework, the SQL database behind, also the AS400 back-end. It introduced several fragile moving parts to do this, but they could swap out Oracle for SQL in this application assuming that someone wrote the EXACT same stored procedures names that had the EXACT same functionality and behind it or swapped out the back-end main frame with an EXACT copy of some other COTS program that communicated over a custom protocol (currently only used on the AS400).

    To answer your questions…I’m very confident (100% so) that for the lifetime of *this* application we will use SQL Server, .NET XML configuration files, and an AS400 main-frame, and EL for logging.

    Now, let’s talk about what I did. I removed every bit of this code that decoupled me.

    Why?

    1) The TCO was sky-rocketing, because every change required re-working interfaces and other layers of abstraction and all the moving parts created by making this flexibility (what you think you get something for nothing?); a project that should take 3 days took 2 weeks.

    2) Bugs from all this late-binding where rampant in production – no compile time checksand there ‘testing’ strategy, well, it was amateur at best.

    3) The likely hood of the organization up and shifting database technologies was maybe 0.000001% – a fortune 500 company isn’t going to suddenly ‘shift’ technologies – and if they do, it’s going to be on a 3 to 5 year plan. 4) The likely hood of the organization up and shifting back-end main-frames is absolute 0% – the company would die if that happened.

    So I think that while DI and IoC *is* academically a good idea, and great for *certain* applications, in the large chunks of the rest of the world it can become cost prohibitive *if* you don’t need it.

    And I think that’s where the real education needs to be taught – when you do vs. do not need it. If you’re writing software to sell on the market – YES – you want absolute flexability. If you’re writing internal software for an IT department for a company that doesn’t generate it’s revenue through selling the software you write – then – NO – you do not *need* absolute flexability – chances are, you’re increasing the total cost of ownership of the application for the company – and some such as myself, might see it as border line ‘gold plating’ (or as Fowler puts it, ‘speculative generalities’.) Then of course there’s all the shades of gray in between.

    And your still not done – you have to take into account the life-time of the application. We as programmers think that are application will live forever and therefore must be able to handle ‘unknowns’ in the future. There’s a scope and product life-cycle for a reason – people know at best your going to get 6-8 years out of an application before it’s obsolete, and that’s being very generous.

    So be careful not to lead young developers astray by allowing them to think that you *always* want to use IoC and DI – remember, there are no silver bullets, and not everything is a nail. You know what I’m getting at and I know that’s not your intent, but people often to *see* that part of it – they just go ‘ooh ahhh gimme gimme’ and run full steam into a wall.

    It was a great article and great presentation, but I had to point out this one key point.

  • http://www.jameskovacs.com james.kovacs

    @Brett – Thanks. Glad that I could be triply helpful.
    @Johan – I guess I owe you a beer too.

  • http://www.jameskovacs.com james.kovacs

    @Brian – Thanks for the comments and glad you enjoyed the show. It sounds to me that your DI/IoC implementation caused you a lot of friction and it was the right idea to strip it out. If it’s not giving you the promised benefit, get rid of it.

    That said, I would disagree with respect to DI/IoC on internal projects. I believe that most projects can benefit from using at least a simple IoC container. Autodiscovery can take a lot of the potential pain out of IoC. Without IoC, it can be just plain onerous to write to contract and not concrete implementation. IoC is not about swapping components (though it can be used that way). It’s about loosely coupled architectures. It’s about testability. It’s about the open/closed principle. It’s about encouraging good software design…

    How do I jive these two views? Ditch IoC and use IoC? Brian’s IoC implementation caused him a lot of grief. He was right to remove something that was causing him undue friction. Personally, rather than ditching IoC completely, I would have considered other options such as: another IoC container; removing IoC from areas causing the most friction; tooling such as ReSharper where I can easily promote a new method to my interface; etc.

    It’s not as black and white as use IoC for commercial software and avoid it for internal. Honestly most applications that I’ve used IoC successfully on have been internal applications. What you do have to decide is whether IoC suits your development style?
